Inflation Signal

Broad U.S. inflation signal from price-level dynamics.

As of 2026-01-10

Gemini Summary

Signal Summary:

  • The Fed Inflation Signal (1) is currently in a COOL regime as of 2026-01-31, with a composite z-score of -0.008551 and a scaled value of 20.317340. This indicates a state of disinflation/deflation risk.
  • The signal has shown a consistent trend towards disinflation, transitioning from NEUTRAL to COOL in April 2025.
  • Conviction Band: High | Interpretation Confidence: High | Internal Conflict Flag: No.

Key Dynamics:

  • The COOL regime is driven by the weighted composite of various inflation pressure indicators, including CPI (headline/core), 10Y breakevens, M2, Fed assets, Industrial Production, copper prices, USD (inverted YoY), Economic Policy Uncertainty, and Fed Funds rate changes (1).
  • The composite's z-score has steadily declined, breaching the -0.5 threshold to indicate disinflationary pressure.
  • Conditional Invalidation: A sustained increase of the composite z-score above -0.5 would move the signal out of the COOL regime and into NEUTRAL.

Scenario Balance:

  • Base Case dominant: Disinflationary pressures are likely to persist, potentially leading to further cooling of inflation.
  • Upside secondary: An unexpected rebound in global demand or significant supply shocks could reignite inflationary pressures.
  • Downside residual: Deeper disinflation, possibly accelerating towards outright deflation, if demand weakens further.

Time Horizon & Aggregation:

  • Time Horizon: Cyclical (months), reflecting the use of monthly data and changes over several months to define regimes.
  • Aggregation Weight Hint: High, due to its comprehensive nature in assessing broad inflation pressures and transparent methodology.

Macro Relevance:

  • This signal primarily informs the Pricing (inflation) macro dimension (1).
  • The COOL regime typically suggests a late-cycle slowdown or early-cycle contraction phase.
  • It interacts strongly with monetary policy expectations, often implying reduced pressure for interest rate hikes and potential for policy easing when combined with labor market slack signals.

Data & References:

  • Primary data from FRED, with the latest observation for the composite signal on 2026-01-31.
  • The core components (headline/core CPI, 10Y breakevens, and money/liquidity proxies) are most influential in determining the composite z-score and regime (1).
  • To improve depth, incorporating the Policy-Relevant Inflation (PCE) Signal (2) or granular wage growth (e.g., Employment Cost Index) could provide further insight into demand-side and cost-push inflation dynamics.
